boat.name: Mersey
boat.full_description:
Mersey was one of ten Rivers Class Yachts built by William  Crossfield and Sons in Arnside for the River Mersey Yacht Club. Six were  built in 1912 with a further four in 1914. Five Rivers Class yachts are  thought to be still in existence: Arnside Sailing Club’s “Severn”  'Deva', 'Dart', 'Styx' (all on the OGA Register) and 'Esk'.

The  Rivers Class were used largely for evening racing with a season running  from May to July, with regatta race in July. The boats were also raced  in August at the Straits Regatta on Anglesey. They were raced for prize  money. In 1914 prize money was £44 when the average wage was £67. The  Royal Mersey Yacht Club was based in Rock Ferry, a then prosperous area  of Birkenhead with large houses overlooking the river.

The  design was based upon the Blackpool and Fleetwood Jewel Class. The boats  were originally opened decked. They had a crew of three. The boats cost  £50 each delivered afloat with a further £14.18s for the sails. (In  total £4000 in 2021 prices, labour was a lot cheaper then).

Mersey was the flagship of the class being owned by Charles Livingstone, the  Vice Commodore of the Club. The Commodore, an honorary position was the  17th Earl of Derby. Charles was related to the founders of the Cunard  and MacIver Shipping Lines. He owned Arudaa 30 tonne yacht and went on to own Kentra, an 85 foot, 94 tonne yacht built by Fifes in Scotland. Kentra is still in existence and has been sailed round the world. Charles  lived in the centre of Liverpool in a large Georgian house on Dale St.  Under Charles Livingstone, Mersey won one race in 1914.

In 1914 Mersey was brought by Lt Hugh McNeille-Gibb, first officer of HMS Conway,  a merchant navy training ship anchored in the Mersey off Rock Ferry. At  the same time his commanding officer Captain Harvey Broadbent acquired  Arnside Sailing Club’s Severn, then known as Ribble.  At one stage Hugh worked for the White Star Line. Hugh McNeille-Gibb was a better sailor than his commanding officer, owning a succession of  larger yachts including Inknoo, which was later owned by Joe Wallace, who restored Severn after she was raised from the bed of the Mersey. One of Hugh’s yachts Caird had to be re-handicapped to stop him winning so many races.

After the First World War Mersey was owned by S. McLauchlan in partnership with a succession of other people till 1937. Mersey won  the Rivers Class series 10 times making her the most successful boat.  In 1935 the Rivers Class were replaced by the Mylne Class.  S.McLauchlan  was instrumental in the selection of the new class. The flagship of  Mylne Class was also called “Mersey”. She was owned by the Earl of Derby, the club’s Commodore.

In 1939 Lloyds Register, Mersey is recorded as being owned by A.Manson of West Kirby in the Wirral. He was a member of the Royal Mersey Yacht and the West Kirby Sailing Club.  There are entries for Mersey in 1947 and 48 Registers. The  boat is recorded as being in Birkenhead though the owner is not named.  She might briefly have been used as a fishing boat in the River Dee.

Either just before the Second World War or after it, Mersey was  moved to Pwllheli and then to Aberystwyth. In 1987 she was owned by  Gron Davies, who mentions that he was restoring her in a letter to the Gaffers Log.
boat.construction_details: Carvel built with counter stern. Pitch pine planks and steamed American elm on English oak frame, larch keelson. Deck spruce on larch decking beams.
boat.short_description: Mersey was one of ten Rivers Class Yachts built by William  Crossfields  and Sons in Arnside for the River Mersey Yacht Club. She  was the flag  ship of the class and won more races than any other boat.
